channel.title: CBS News Weekend Roundup
channel.itunes:subtitle: CBS News Weekend Roundup
channel.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
channel.itunes:summary: Washington Correspondent Dan Raviv wraps up the week's news and goes deep into the tough stories. It's the best one-stop shopping there is to catch up on the news.
channel.description: Washington Correspondent Dan Raviv wraps up the news of the week and goes deep into the tough stories with CBS News correspondents. The best one-stop shopping there is to catch up on the news.

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 06/01
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: CBS News Correspondent Gary Nunn reports the May unemployment numbers show continued weakness. Correspondent Nancy Cordes and senior legal analyst Andrew Cohen report on a Court of Appeals ruling that the Defense of Marriage Act is unconstitutional for denying federal benefits to same-sex couples. Correspondent Michelle Miller reports on the attempt by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg to restrict the sale of large cups of sugary drinks. All that and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup...
item.description: CBS News Correspondent Gary Nunn reports the May unemployment numbers show continued weakness. Correspondent Nancy Cordes and senior legal analyst Andrew Cohen report on a Court of Appeals ruling that the Defense of Marriage Act is unconstitutional for denying federal benefits to same-sex couples. Correspondent Michelle Miller reports on the attempt by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg to restrict the sale of large cups of sugary drinks. All that and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup...
item.itunes:keywords: Unemployment, Soda, Defense of Marriage Act
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 05/25
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: CBS News Senior Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports on the botched Facebook IPO, White House Correspondent Peter Maer on the NATO summit in Chicago, National Correspondent Dan Raviv with Correspondent Elizabeth Palmer in Cairo on the Egyptian presidential elections and Correspondent Pam Coulter on record low mortgage rates. All that on the CBS News Weekend Roundup...
item.description: CBS News Senior Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports on the botched Facebook IPO, White House Correspondent Peter Maer on the NATO summit in Chicago, National Correspondent Dan Raviv with Correspondent Elizabeth Palmer in Cairo on the Egyptian presidential elections and Correspondent Pam Coulter on record low mortgage rates. All that on the CBS News Weekend Roundup...
item.itunes:keywords: Facebook IPO, NATO Summit, Campaign 2012, SpaceX, Shakil Afridi, Egyptian presidential elections, Mortgage Rates, Cat Cafe
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 05/18
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: CBS News Business Reporter Alexis Christoforous and Jill Schlesinger, of CBSMarketWatch.com, report on the Initial Public Offering for Facebook. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv chats with military consultant (ret.) Col. Jeff McCausland about the agreement on Afghanistan on the table at the NATO summit in Chicago. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports from the Pentagon on an oxygen supply problem for pilots flying the F-22 fighter jet. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv interviews former Rep. Patrick Kennedy about the Mujahedin-e-Khalq and why he is calling for the government to take the MEK off its list of foreign terrorist organizations.Correspondent Jim Taylor, as part of his series "Now. What," looks at the lasting impact of radio. That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup
item.description: CBS News Business Reporter Alexis Christoforous and Jill Schlesinger, of CBSMarketWatch.com, report on the Initial Public Offering for Facebook. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv chats with military consultant (ret.) Col. Jeff McCausland about the agreement on Afghanistan on the table at the NATO summit in Chicago. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports from the Pentagon on an oxygen supply problem for pilots flying the F-22 fighter jet. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv interviews former Rep. Patrick Kennedy about the Mujahedin-e-Khalq and why he is calling for the government to take the MEK off its list of foreign terrorist organizations.Correspondent Jim Taylor, as part of his series "Now. What," looks at the lasting impact of radio. That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 05/11
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Senior Correspondent John Miller reports on an Al Qaeda airliner bombing attempt stopped by a double-agent in Yemen. Correspondent Bill Whitaker reports on reaction among Hispanics in California to President Obama's support for same-sex marriage. Senior Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports on a $2 billion trading loss at JpMorgan Chase.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Senior Correspondent John Miller reports on an Al Qaeda airliner bombing attempt stopped by a double-agent in Yemen. Correspondent Bill Whitaker reports on reaction among Hispanics in California to President Obama's support for same-sex marriage. Senior Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports on a $2 billion trading loss at JpMorgan Chase.
item.itunes:keywords: Al Qaeda, Underwear Bomber, Same-Sex Marriage, HIV, Mitt Romney, J.P. Morgan Chase, Medicare fraud, End of the World
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 05/04
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondents Sam Litzinger and Howard Arenstein report on reaction to a fairly weak jobs report. Correspondent Celia Hatton reports on the first stage of the deal to allow Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng to leave the American embassy in Beijing. Brandi Kruse, of KIRO Radio in Seattle reports on May Day unrest by "Occupy" protesters in Washington State.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondents Sam Litzinger and Howard Arenstein report on reaction to a fairly weak jobs report. Correspondent Celia Hatton reports on the first stage of the deal to allow Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng to leave the American embassy in Beijing. Brandi Kruse, of KIRO Radio in Seattle reports on May Day unrest by "Occupy" protesters in Washington State.
item.itunes:keywords: Health Care, Mitt Romney, Chen Guangcheng, May Day, Occupy, Roger Clemens, A&M University drum major, Unemployment
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 04/27
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: On the CBS News Weekend Roundup with Dan Raviv, the latest surrounding the Secret Service scandal with Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell, Mitt Romney's five-state sweep in the week's GOP primaries, the approaching first anniversary of Osama Bin Laden's killing and Shuttle Enterprise's arrival in New York.
item.description: On the CBS News Weekend Roundup with Dan Raviv, the latest surrounding the Secret Service scandal with Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell, Mitt Romney's five-state sweep in the week's GOP primaries, the approaching first anniversary of Osama Bin Laden's killing and Shuttle Enterprise's arrival in New York.
item.itunes:keywords: Secret Service, Primary, Norah O'Donnell, Mitt Romney, Osama Bin Laden, Gas Prices
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 04/20
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell reports on the Secet Service scandal. Correspondent Cami McCormick reports on the latest photos of American soldiers posing with Taliban corpses in Afghanistan. And Director of Surveys Sarah Dutton and Chief Washington Correspondent Bob Schieffer talk about the latest CBS News/New York Times Poll on the Presidential race.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell reports on the Secet Service scandal. Correspondent Cami McCormick reports on the latest photos of American soldiers posing with Taliban corpses in Afghanistan. And Director of Surveys Sarah Dutton and Chief Washington Correspondent Bob Schieffer talk about the latest CBS News/New York Times Poll on the Presidential race.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 04/14/12
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: Weekend Roundup: 04/14/12
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 04/06
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: Correspondent Gary Nunn and Jill Schlesinger of CBSMoneyWatch.com, report on the unemployment figures; Correspondent Lee Cowan reports on the shooting at Oakland's Oikos University. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports on the announcement of military tribunals for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and four other 9/11 co-conspirators. Correspondent Peter King speaks with Baseball Hall of Fame broadcaster Milo Hamilton, and Correspondent Steve Futterman reports from Miami's new Marlins Park on Major League Baseball's opening night. Those stories on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.description: Correspondent Gary Nunn and Jill Schlesinger of CBSMoneyWatch.com, report on the unemployment figures; Correspondent Lee Cowan reports on the shooting at Oakland's Oikos University. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports on the announcement of military tribunals for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and four other 9/11 co-conspirators. Correspondent Peter King speaks with Baseball Hall of Fame broadcaster Milo Hamilton, and Correspondent Steve Futterman reports from Miami's new Marlins Park on Major League Baseball's opening night. Those stories on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 03/30
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In the CBS News Weekend Roundup we focus on the Supreme Court's historic sessions to consider the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act, the extension of the Transportation Bill, the continuing controversy over the killing of teenager Trayvon Martin, Pope Benedict's visit to Cuba and Mexico, President Obama's visit to South Korea for a nuclear summit, and a new book about what it's like to protect the President of the United States.
item.description: In the CBS News Weekend Roundup we focus on the Supreme Court's historic sessions to consider the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act, the extension of the Transportation Bill, the continuing controversy over the killing of teenager Trayvon Martin, Pope Benedict's visit to Cuba and Mexico, President Obama's visit to South Korea for a nuclear summit, and a new book about what it's like to protect the President of the United States.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 03/23
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup with National Correspondent Dan Raviv, Correspondents Elaine Cobbe and Elizabeth Palmer report on the gun battle in Toulouse, France that ended the life of a radical Islamist responsible for the deaths of seven people. Military consultant Jeff McCausland talks about how the shootings may affect Afghanistan exit strategy. Correspondent Steve Futterman reports the New Orleans Saints have been penalized for offering players bounties to injure opponents. Dan Raviv interviews Michael Widlanski, author of "Battle for Our Minds: Western Elites and the Terror Threat." That and more on this week's CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup with National Correspondent Dan Raviv, Correspondents Elaine Cobbe and Elizabeth Palmer report on the gun battle in Toulouse, France that ended the life of a radical Islamist responsible for the deaths of seven people. Military consultant Jeff McCausland talks about how the shootings may affect Afghanistan exit strategy. Correspondent Steve Futterman reports the New Orleans Saints have been penalized for offering players bounties to injure opponents. Dan Raviv interviews Michael Widlanski, author of "Battle for Our Minds: Western Elites and the Terror Threat." That and more on this week's CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 03/16
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Dan Raviv reports Rick Santorum scored the headlines, but Mitt Romney won the most delegates on Tuesday. CBS's Jan Crawford and John Dickerson analyze what Santorum, Romney, and Newt Gingrich want now. At the Pentagon, David Martin reports on the murder of 16 civilians in Afghanistan allegedly by an American soldier and Defense Secretary Leon Panetta talks about it with CBS's Chip Reid.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Dan Raviv reports Rick Santorum scored the headlines, but Mitt Romney won the most delegates on Tuesday. CBS's Jan Crawford and John Dickerson analyze what Santorum, Romney, and Newt Gingrich want now. At the Pentagon, David Martin reports on the murder of 16 civilians in Afghanistan allegedly by an American soldier and Defense Secretary Leon Panetta talks about it with CBS's Chip Reid.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 03/09
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: Correspondent Steve Kathan reviews the results of Super Tuesday along with Correspondent Peter Maer at Mitt Romney's victory celebration in Boston, Correspondent Barry Bagnato in Steubenville, Ohio at Rick Santorum's rally, Correspondent Peter King in Atlanta where Newt Gingrich celebrated a win in Georgia and Reporter August Skamenca who spoke to voters about their preferences in Oklahoma City.Correspondent Lesley Stahl, on "60 Minutes," spoke to Meir Dagan, the former head of Mossad, about the dangers of Israel attacking Iran. Jill Schlesinger, Editor-at-Large for CBS MoneyWatch.com, talks about the latest unemployment figures.On "CBS This Morning," Political Correspondent Jan Crawford interviewed Karen Santorum, the wife of Republican presidential hopeful Rick Santorum. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv continues his interview with Alex Berenson, author of "The Shadow Patrol." That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.description: Correspondent Steve Kathan reviews the results of Super Tuesday along with Correspondent Peter Maer at Mitt Romney's victory celebration in Boston, Correspondent Barry Bagnato in Steubenville, Ohio at Rick Santorum's rally, Correspondent Peter King in Atlanta where Newt Gingrich celebrated a win in Georgia and Reporter August Skamenca who spoke to voters about their preferences in Oklahoma City.Correspondent Lesley Stahl, on "60 Minutes," spoke to Meir Dagan, the former head of Mossad, about the dangers of Israel attacking Iran. Jill Schlesinger, Editor-at-Large for CBS MoneyWatch.com, talks about the latest unemployment figures.On "CBS This Morning," Political Correspondent Jan Crawford interviewed Karen Santorum, the wife of Republican presidential hopeful Rick Santorum. CBS News National Correspondent Dan Raviv continues his interview with Alex Berenson, author of "The Shadow Patrol." That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.itunes:keywords: Super Tuesday, Meir Dagan, Israel, Iran, Unemployment, Alex Berenson
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 03/02
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Dan Raviv describes the Republican candidates' positions on foreign policy and immigration reform. Correspondent Clarissa Ward reports from Lebanon on the latest violence in Syria's crackdown against regime opponents. Correspondent Cami McCormick reports on Egypt's release of American aid workers. National Correspondent Dean Reynolds reports on death and damage caused by tornadoes in the Midwest. And Correspondent Elizabeth Palmer reports from Tehran on Iranian parliamentary elections.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Dan Raviv describes the Republican candidates' positions on foreign policy and immigration reform. Correspondent Clarissa Ward reports from Lebanon on the latest violence in Syria's crackdown against regime opponents. Correspondent Cami McCormick reports on Egypt's release of American aid workers. National Correspondent Dean Reynolds reports on death and damage caused by tornadoes in the Midwest. And Correspondent Elizabeth Palmer reports from Tehran on Iranian parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 02/24
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: CBS News Chief Political Correspondent Jan Crawford reports on the 20th Republican debate, the last before Super Tuesday and Tuesday's primaries in Michigan and Arizona. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports that American troops are facing Afghan protests over the burning of Korans at a U.S. military base. Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell reports on the politics of the rise in the price of gas. Correspondent Charlie Rose, on "CBS This Morning," interviewed former House Speaker Newt Gingrich about the Republican primary in Michigan and Pat Buchanan about his new book. Dan Raviv speaks with Gail Rubin, author of "A Good Goodbye: Funeral Planning for Those Who Don't Plan to Die." Dan also talks to James Kunen, author of "Diary of a Company Man: Losing a Job, Finding a Life." That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.description: CBS News Chief Political Correspondent Jan Crawford reports on the 20th Republican debate, the last before Super Tuesday and Tuesday's primaries in Michigan and Arizona. National Security Correspondent David Martin reports that American troops are facing Afghan protests over the burning of Korans at a U.S. military base. Chief White House Correspondent Norah O'Donnell reports on the politics of the rise in the price of gas. Correspondent Charlie Rose, on "CBS This Morning," interviewed former House Speaker Newt Gingrich about the Republican primary in Michigan and Pat Buchanan about his new book. Dan Raviv speaks with Gail Rubin, author of "A Good Goodbye: Funeral Planning for Those Who Don't Plan to Die." Dan also talks to James Kunen, author of "Diary of a Company Man: Losing a Job, Finding a Life." That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 02/17/12
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: Dan chats with White House Correspondent Peter Maer about President Obama's new proposed budget.National Security consultant Juan Zarate talks about the "shadow war" between Iran and Israel. Dan chats with Correspondent Steve Futterman about the sudden NBA success of Jeremy Lin of the N.Y. Knicks.President Obama told Charlotte CBS TV affiliate WBTV why he decided to encourage rich supporters to donate to his Super PAC even though he opposes the practice. Dan speaks about these unlimited political donations with Lawrence Lessig, author of "One Way Forward: The Outsider's Guide to Fixing the Republic." Correspondent Scott Pelley, of "The CBS Evening News," remembers the White House Tour given by First Lady Jackie Kennedy 50 years ago.That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.description: Dan chats with White House Correspondent Peter Maer about President Obama's new proposed budget.National Security consultant Juan Zarate talks about the "shadow war" between Iran and Israel. Dan chats with Correspondent Steve Futterman about the sudden NBA success of Jeremy Lin of the N.Y. Knicks.President Obama told Charlotte CBS TV affiliate WBTV why he decided to encourage rich supporters to donate to his Super PAC even though he opposes the practice. Dan speaks about these unlimited political donations with Lawrence Lessig, author of "One Way Forward: The Outsider's Guide to Fixing the Republic." Correspondent Scott Pelley, of "The CBS Evening News," remembers the White House Tour given by First Lady Jackie Kennedy 50 years ago.That and more on the CBS News Weekend Roundup.
item.itunes:keywords: NBA, Knicks, Obama, President, Super PAC, Jackie Kennedy,
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 02/10
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: CBS News Political Director John Dickerson analyzes Rick Santorum's triple win in Republican presidential contests in Colorado, Minnesota and Missouri and what it means for his main rivals, Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich. Correspondent Clarissa Ward reports on the increasingly violent crackdown against rebel fighters by the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad. Correspondent Heather Bosch reports on the 911 call from a social worker after she brought two children to the home of Josh Powell, who then killed himself and his sons. Correspondent Wyatt Andrews gets reaction at Catholic University in washington, D.C. on the controversy over birth control. Correspondent Barry Bagnato reports on a new study showing doctors are not always honest with their patients about medical mistakes.
item.description: CBS News Political Director John Dickerson analyzes Rick Santorum's triple win in Republican presidential contests in Colorado, Minnesota and Missouri and what it means for his main rivals, Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich. Correspondent Clarissa Ward reports on the increasingly violent crackdown against rebel fighters by the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad. Correspondent Heather Bosch reports on the 911 call from a social worker after she brought two children to the home of Josh Powell, who then killed himself and his sons. Correspondent Wyatt Andrews gets reaction at Catholic University in washington, D.C. on the controversy over birth control. Correspondent Barry Bagnato reports on a new study showing doctors are not always honest with their patients about medical mistakes.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 02/03/12
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: Correspondent Pam Coulter reports from Tampa on Mitt Romney's big win in Florida's Republican primary. Jill Schesinger, of CBSMoneyWatch.com, comments on the latest unemployment figures.National Security Correspondent David Martin reports on the Syrian uprising and the possibility of a civil war against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad. Dan interviews Laura Schroff, co-author of "An Invisible Thread: The True Story of an 11-Year-Old Panhandler, a Busy Sales Executive, and an Unlikely Meeting with Destiny."Correspondent Sam Litzinger reports the The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation backed down from its decision to cut funding for Planned Parenthood.
item.description: Correspondent Pam Coulter reports from Tampa on Mitt Romney's big win in Florida's Republican primary. Jill Schesinger, of CBSMoneyWatch.com, comments on the latest unemployment figures.National Security Correspondent David Martin reports on the Syrian uprising and the possibility of a civil war against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad. Dan interviews Laura Schroff, co-author of "An Invisible Thread: The True Story of an 11-Year-Old Panhandler, a Busy Sales Executive, and an Unlikely Meeting with Destiny."Correspondent Sam Litzinger reports the The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation backed down from its decision to cut funding for Planned Parenthood.
item.itunes:keywords: Romney, GOP, Unemployment, Susan G. Komen for the Cure, Planned Parenthood, Syria,
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 01/27
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: Correspondent Peter King previews Tuesday's Florida primary as Mitt Romney tries to stop Newt Gingrich's momentum. Senior White House Correspondent Bill Plante reports on President Obama's State of the Union address. Correspondent Charlie Rose, on "CBS This Morning," interviewed Vice President Joe Biden about the speech. Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports five major banks have agreed to a draft settlement on mortgage foreclosures. Dan Raviv interviews Eliot Cohen, author of "Conquered into Liberty," on how Americans have fought wars through history. Reporter August Skamenca reports from Yellowstone National Park where efforts to control the buffalo population have triggered concern.
item.description: Correspondent Peter King previews Tuesday's Florida primary as Mitt Romney tries to stop Newt Gingrich's momentum. Senior White House Correspondent Bill Plante reports on President Obama's State of the Union address. Correspondent Charlie Rose, on "CBS This Morning," interviewed Vice President Joe Biden about the speech. Business Correspondent Anthony Mason reports five major banks have agreed to a draft settlement on mortgage foreclosures. Dan Raviv interviews Eliot Cohen, author of "Conquered into Liberty," on how Americans have fought wars through history. Reporter August Skamenca reports from Yellowstone National Park where efforts to control the buffalo population have triggered concern.
item.itunes:keywords: GOP, Weekend Roundup, round up, President, Biden, speech, State of the Union, banks, mortgage, Cohen, author, history, National park
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News

item.title: Weekend Roundup: 01/21
item.itunes:author: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:subtitle: CBS Radio News
item.itunes:summary: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Jim Krasula reports many voters were undecided on the eve of the South Carolina primary. Correspondent Wyatt Andrews reports that President Obama has decided not to proceed with the Keystone Pipeline. Congressional Correspondent Bob Fuss reports that two bills aimed at stopping online piracy triggered Internet protests. And Correspondent Allen Pizzey reports from Italy on the crash of the Costa Concordia cruise ship and charges that Captain Francesco Schettino abandoned ship.
item.description: In this edition of the CBS News Weekend Roundup, Correspondent Jim Krasula reports many voters were undecided on the eve of the South Carolina primary. Correspondent Wyatt Andrews reports that President Obama has decided not to proceed with the Keystone Pipeline. Congressional Correspondent Bob Fuss reports that two bills aimed at stopping online piracy triggered Internet protests. And Correspondent Allen Pizzey reports from Italy on the crash of the Costa Concordia cruise ship and charges that Captain Francesco Schettino abandoned ship.
item.dc:creator: CBS Radio News
